from our on-premise experience Active
Directory provides great benefits for
end-users users can sign in with user
IDs and passwords or even certificates
giving them a single sign-on experience
from their desktops to access corporate
applications Active Directory also gives
corporate applications the ability to
utilize Kerberos tickets that were
issued to the clients which the
application can then use to verify who
the user is the application can also
identify which groups that the user
belongs to and then perform access
control based on that group membership
making administration of the application
more convenient Active Directory also
has the concept of Group Policy baked in
giving administrators the ability to
apply different policy for the users and
the computers that are members of the
domain with Group Policy you can apply
specific scripts or machine
configurations at login and log off and
group policy can be applied to specific
organizational units so you can set
permissions to all members of the
or apply policy at lower levels of the
hierarchy and those policies will then
be inherited by all child members of
that hierarchy this gives you a
convenient means of applying policy to
large numbers of users and computers and
finally while we believe that over time
our customers will be moving all of
their workloads to the cloud we are also
committed to ways that make AWS an
extension of your on-premise environment

in the cloud is a key component of

so customers really have three choices
of how to integrate Active Directory
into their Windows workloads on AWS
first AWS offers a managed Active
Directory solution using AWS Microsoft
ad this is a completely managed service
with monitoring patching and snapshots
handled automatically by AWS second a
